page.title: 15Curious Morwenstow
page.content: The {Reverend Robert Stephen Hawker liked to leave crosses in his wake, as in the window of his cottage in{Coombe on the gable of the school which he had built near{Shop}and in the Cornish cross which he had brought from the moor to his churchyard in 1850. With financial aid from {King William {VI}he built the bridge into the parish which crosses the river at{Coombe. {Hawker's Hut}of driftwood is still to be seen on the top of{Vicarage Cliff. He also constructed the vicarage with its curious and unique chimneys. Nearby is {St. John's Well}which still supplies the church with christening water. {St Morwenna's Well }' halfway down a precipice ' is now alas dry. However, the parish is host to a much greater stream. On {Woolley moor }rises that seminal Cornish river,{The Tamar.
